description: Evaluation rubric for extracurricular activities and involvement

depth_vs_breadth.description: Does the student show deep commitment to a few activities rather than superficial involvement in many?

criteria: 2-3 activities with exceptional depth (4+ years, significant hours)
Clear progression and growth within activities
Mastery or significant achievement in focus areas
Activities align with interests and tell a coherent story
Strong commitment to key activities (2-3 years)
Good balance of depth with some breadth
Clear investment of time and energy
Some activities show commitment, others are brief
Mix of depth and superficial involvement
Potential visible but not fully developed
Many activities but little depth in any
No clear focus or passion area
Activities are one-time or minimal commitment

leadership_initiative.description: Does the student demonstrate leadership, initiative, or entrepreneurial spirit?

criteria: Created something new or drove significant change
Others looked to them for direction and inspiration
Contributed to growth or improvement of activities
Some leadership experience (committee chair, section leader)
Takes on responsibility when given opportunity
Primarily a participant, not a leader
No evidence of initiative or self-direction

impact_achievement.description: What tangible impact or achievements has the student accomplished?

criteria: Quantifiable significant impact (raised $X, helped Y people, grew org by Z%)
Awards or honors at highest levels
Published work, patents, or professional-level accomplishments
Clear positive impact with measurable results
Expertise or skill level above peers
Solid track record without standout achievements

authenticity_passion.description: Do the activities reflect genuine interests rather than resume-building?

criteria: Activities clearly driven by genuine passion
Coherent story or theme across activities
Would clearly continue activities even without college benefit
Activities connect to personal values and identity
Some strategic choices but mostly genuine
Activities reflect who the student is
Mix of genuine and strategic activities
Activities don't tell a clear story
Hard to identify what truly drives the student
Checking boxes rather than pursuing interests
Activities feel disconnected from who the student is

activity_tiers.description: Framework for evaluating the significance of individual activities

tier_1.name: Exceptional/National
examples: Patent holder or significant research contribution

research.description: Genuine research experience, especially with publication or presentation

entrepreneurship.description: Started business, social enterprise, or self-directed project with real impact

work_experience.description: Significant employment, especially if supporting family or with high responsibility

family_responsibilities.description: Caring for siblings, elderly relatives, or contributing to family business

unique_talent.description: Exceptional skill in unusual area that demonstrates dedication

red_flags.description: Activities don't match stated interests or intended major
Heavy activity involvement only in junior/senior year (resume building)
Cannot articulate role, impact, or learning from activities
Minimal or no extracurricular involvement without explanation

feedback_templates.strength: Your {activity} demonstrates {quality}. The {specific_detail} is particularly impressive and shows {what_it_shows}.
feedback_templates.suggestion: Consider {suggestion} to strengthen your activity profile. This would demonstrate {benefit}.
feedback_templates.narrative: Your activities tell a story of {theme}. Admissions committees will appreciate {what_they_see}.
feedback_templates.improvement: Your activity profile would benefit from {improvement}. Focus on {specific_focus} rather than {what_to_avoid}.
